comments: Related sequence b(n) = Number of digits in 2^n that are at least 5. a(0) = 1, b(0) = 0 and a(n+1) = b(n), as a digit with value 5 of higher in 2^n will generate an odd digit in 2^(n+1). In the Nieuw Archief voor Wiskunde link there is a proof that sum(k>=, b(k)/2^k) = 2/9. - _Jaap Spies_, Mar 13 2009
references: J. Borwein, D. Bailey and R. Girgensohn, Experimentation in mathematics : computational paths to discovery, A. K. Peters, 2004, pp. 14-15
links: Seiichi Manyama, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
Nieuw Archief voor Wiskunde, Problemen/UWC, p174-175, June 2004.
formula: Sum(k>=0,a(k)/2^k)=11/9 (for a proof see the comment above). [Corrected by _Jaap Spies_, Mar 13 2009]
example: 2^30 = 1073741824 and 1073741824 contains 5 odd decimal digits hence a(30)=5.
maple: A055254 := proc(val) local i, j, k, n; n := 2^val; j := 0; k := floor(ln(n)/ln(10))+1; for i from 1 to k do if (n mod 10) mod 2 = 1 then j := j+1 fi; n := floor(n/10); od; RETURN(j); end: seq(A055254(n),n=0..110); # _Jaap Spies_
